title: iain-macwhirter-john-mcdonnells-edinburgh-declaration-caught-scottish-political-world-completely-surprise
story: If anyone tells you that theyd expected this, theyre lying. McDonnells Edinburgh Declaration caught the Scottish political world completely by surprise. The SNP couldnt believe their ears. I initially thought his remarks, especially the reference to ldquothe English Parliament, were just a badly-briefed UK politician talking off the cuff. But no. It is now apparently UK Labour policy to accept the SNPrsquos call for ldquoindyref. Gobs were well and truly smacked.Most smacked of all were the Scottish Labour Partys. Their leader, Richard Leonard, was left speechless. The Shadow Chancellor had directly contradicted Labours  manesto promise to oppose a repeat referendum. Only in March, Leonard made clear in an interview with the Daily Record, that a future Labour government would, like Theresa May, refuse any request for a ldquoSection  Order to trigger a legally-binding referendum on independence. No s no buts.:Scottish Labour registers lowest level of income in nearly two decadesNot any more, it seems. The Branch Office, as the SNP like to call Scottish Labour, has been told to back the policy of their deadly enemy. Christmas has come early for Nicola Sturgeon, without the turkeys.Many Scottish Labour MSPs were incandescent, as was the former Labour shadow Scottish secretary Ian Murray MP, who called McDonnell ldquoludicrous and demanded that he ldquoapologise to Richard Leonard , and reaffirm Labours policy of opposition to a referendum . Off-the-record comments from Scottish Labour figures were unprintable. Unionist Labour MSPs put together a statement ldquodeploring" the change in policy. This backfired when it emerged they hadnt cleared it with Richard Leonards office.The Labour MP, Paul Sweeney, then added to the confusion by calling for a multi-option referendum including federalism, or devo max as it used to be called. This was once proposed by Alex Salmond in , and rejected by Labour and the Conservatives in favour of a binary Yes No question. Saying Labour were all over the place would be an insult to geography.So, what on earth is going on  Why was one of the key figures in the UK Labour party provoking a split on one of the most contentious issues in British politics  And right in the middle of the Brexit row. Labour is now ided every which way on the constitution: over Scottish independence and over leaving Europe. McDonnell has left the Scottish party an impossible task: trying to win Scottish votes without a policy on Scotland in a general election thats possibly weeks away.:Scottish Labour breaks silence over anti-semitism investigation by blasting "biased" BBCWhat seems to have happened is this. Labour, at a UK level, has started to think about forming much wider political alliances in future in order to defeat the rising tide of the right. This has been discussed by a number of Labour people, including the former BBC economics editor Paul Mason in his book Clear Bright Future.Mason has argues that Labour should abandon its traditional base in the white working class and the trades union movement, and look to creating a new progressive alliance, or ldquopopular front, with LGBT and BAME groups, and with other progressive political parties. Mason regards the SNP, unlike most other nationalist parties, as progressive and social democratic. On the eve of McDonnells Edinburgh interview Mason called infor ldquoa penalty-free independence referendum whenever Holyrood chooses.Im not saying that Paul Mason is writing Labour policy. Far from it. Many in the party regard him with suspicion, not least for appearing to abandon the working class. But it looks asthe Labour leadership has finally been persuaded that the SNP is not just a band of ldquotartan Tories, and that Jeremy Corbyn could do business with Nicola Sturgeon.Scottish Labour is anyway likely to be crushed again in the forthcoming General Wlection, while the SNP is in line for around  Westminster seats according to the polls. Its support would almost certainly be requiredLabour is to try to form a government, and McDonnells intervention could be an attempt to prepare the ground. Theres been no love lost between Corbyn and the mostly Blairite rump of the Scottish Labour Party, so he probably regards them as expendable.Not that Labour is admitting any of this. Indeed, the line from McDonnell in Edinburgh, echoed by the Shadow Business Secretary, Rebecca Long-Bailey on Newsnight, is that Labour will not form any ldquocoalitions or pacts with anyone. Labour is still smarting from those Tory election posters in  which showed the then leader, Ed Miliband, in Alex Salmonds breast pocket. It is imperative for Labour, in England at least, to deny any hint of an alliance with the SNP.But Scotland is a dferent. A ing Labour government in Westminster would require the tacit assistance of the SNP, perhaps on a confidence and supply basis. At any rate, the UK party leadership seems to have decided that offering a referendum is a risk worth taking to help some future co-operation to happen. This is huge development and raises questions about whether Labour can still be called a Unionist party.Paul Hutcheon: the biggest threat to the Union is Scottish Labours disintegrationLast week felt asa dam has broken. After three years in which Scottish politics has been in suspended animation, suddenly everyone was talking about independence again. Even Conservative commentators like The Times Iain Martin are now calling for a referendum in five years. s Simon Jenkins believes independence itself is now unavoidable, and called on Westminster to plan for it now.Of course, a referendum may not deliver a Yes. The polls still show Scotland split down the middle on independence. But this is a vindication of Nicola Sturgeons cautious, constitutional approach to winning independence. It is a blow to her critics, who had been calling for an unauthorised referendum, or even UDI. The former SNP MP, George Kerevan, had been calling for mass civil disobedience to obstruct London transport. But this is a blow her internal critics will be happy to take for there is now a real possibility of a referendum in the next couple of years.That isLabour manages to defeat Boris Johnson ndash a big ask, perhaps, but far from impossible. There will likely be a vote of no confidence the Tory PM next month, and he will almost certainly lose. If Labour fails to form an alternative government in  days, then Johnson has to call a General Election. Hes hoping to delay polling day until after Brexit on October . But that is a risky tactic. Such constitutional jiggery pokery could easily alienate voters, many of whom are anyway unconvinced by Johnsons abilities.Just about anything could happen in the next few weeks. But what is not in doubt is that Scottish independence, or at least a referendum, is back on the agenda. And almost exactly five years since the last one.

title: revealed-uk-shoppers-want-39-perfect-39-community-high-street
story: In a land of strip malls, edge-of-town supermarkets and soulless retail parks, shoppers still dream of traditional mom and pop stores.A survey , adults has found a real community shopping street should have baker, a butcher, a barber, post office, and hardware store.And even in an era of downloads, those surveyed said they would want a record shop.So we all know want makes the perfect high street. But where can we find them Well, forty are now vying to be officially named the best in Britain - based on their shopping experience and community initiatives.In Scotland, Turrf and Alness High Street are in the running alongside Prestwick Main Street, while Wales has Narbeth, Treorchy and Swansea High Streets under consideration.English high streets shortlisted in the Champion High Street Category are Hitchin Town Centre, Freeman Street in Grimsby and Belper in Derbyshire.For Northern Irish shoppers, Newtownards High Street, Enniskillen Town Centre and Bow Street, Lisburn, are up for the prize.The eventual winner will be required to demonstrate their commitment to their local community, great customer experience, an environmental mindset and innovative approach to retail.Judges will also visit each destination on the shortlist, to get a feel for its personality and general ambience.The winning street will be awarded the coveted Great British High Street  trophy, and a pound, cash prize to put towards a local high street initiative.The announcement follows research commissioned by Visa, in partnership with the Great British High Street demonstrating the positive impact the local high street has on communities.Seven in  consumers say shopping locally makes them feel happier, compared to shopping online or at a shopping centre - the main reason being that they know where their money is going.Half of consumers also feel their high street gives them a sense of pride in their local community.Spending time with friends and familyand offering a sense of communitywere other reasons cited for why high streets make people happier.After a rigorous selection process,  high streets from the South East of England to the Scottish Highlands have been shortlisted in the Champion High Street category, which recognises the nationrsquos best high streets.Additionally,  high streets have been shortlisted in the Rising Star category, identying those which are taking the lead to adapt and ersy.Sundeep Kaur, head of UK  Ireland merchant services at Visa, said: ldquoWersquove seen some fantastic entries for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards across both the Champion High Street and Rising Star categories.ldquoIn particular, the desire to innovate stands out among this yearrsquos entries, with high streets adapting to the challenges presented by a rapidly changing retail environment to find ways to thrive at a local level.ldquoAs our research shows, high streets play a vital role at the heart of communities, so this is a great opportunity for those communities with shortlisted high streets to show their support by placing their votes on the Great British High Street website.Last yearrsquos winner was Crickhowell High Street in Wales, located in a bustling rural town nestled in the Usk Valley on the edge of the Brecon BeaconsIt was commended for its community-led initiatives and strong network of independent businesses.High Streets Minister Jake Berry MP said: ldquoCongratulations to the shortlisted nominees for this yearrsquos Great British High Street Awards ndash the quality of the entries this year has been fantastic.ldquoHigh streets make people happier, and people want to see their hard-earned cash supporting the local economy.ldquoThat is why we are celebrating those that go above and beyond to keep their high streets thriving for generations to come.ldquoInspiring high streets like these will play a key role in the Governmentrsquos vision to boost local growth and level up our regions.Out-of-town malls and online shopping have decimated community high streets. But this week Doug Gurr, UK boss of Amazon, the worlds biggest internet vendor, insisted physical retail ndash which is  per cent of UK shopping by value ndash was working hand-in-hand with e-commerce working to drive growth.Shortlisted high streets ndash Champion High Street categoryEngland. title: safety-alert-brake-issues-blamed-caledonian-sleeper-emergency
story: The Rail Accident Investigation Branch raised their concerns over brake failure while launching an investigation into how the Lowland Sleeper sparked an emergency at Edinburgh Waverley station.The RAIB said the train eventually came to a halt, but over  yards beyond its intended stopping point.While there was no damage or any injuries as a result of the incident the RAIB said the outcome could "potentially have been worse, had it led to a collision with another train".:Brake issues to Caledonian Sleeper caused emergency at Edinburgh WaverleyInvestigators say that on the approach to Edinburgh at .am on August , the driver discovered that the trains braking performance was "well below normal" and it "failed to stop as scheduled".An RAIB preliminary investigation indicated that he had no control of the brakes on the coaches because a brake pipe isolating valve was in the closed position when the train left Carstairs station.The RAIB said this meant that the only effective brakes on the train as it approached Edinburgh were those on the locomotive, which were "insufficient to maintain control of the train".Now it has emerged the Sleepertrain operator Serco issued a safety alertto the industry in relation to the incident, four days later.The RAIB said the reminded railway staff of the importance of "carrying out a brake continuity test after all other train preparation activities".Neither the RAIB, Serco or the Rail Safety and Standards Board would allow sight of the alert.:Investigation underway after Caledonian Sleeper overshot  at Edinburgh WaverleyThe train was eventually brought to a stand still by the operation of an emergency device in one of the coaches by the train manager, which caused the train brakes to apply.The incident meant services to London, Dunbar, North Berwick and Tweedbank were cancelled or delayed, before the train was pushed back to the .The Caledonian Sleeper has suffered a number of setbacks since it relaunched with a new poundm fleet in April. On its first night, both north and southbound trains rolled into Glasgow and Euston hours behind schedule.Manuel Cortes, general secretary of The Transport Salaried Staffs Association union called for speedy action over the incident.He said: ldquoOnly good luck and the quick thinking of the train manager saved the passengers on the morning of August . We cannot rely on luck to keep passengers safe.ldquoThe failure of the brakes could have led to a catastrophic accident. We need to find out as soon as possible what led to the brake valve not being opened and then act to put in place whatever is needed for this not to happen again.

title: lonely-planet-top-500-edinburgh-fringe-uks-star-attraction
story: Whether yoursquore a first-time tourist or a slightly jaded local, there is no escaping the fact that therersquos is nothing quite like the Edinburgh Fringe Festival ndash which has today been named the UKrsquos star attraction.The festival, which last year comprised of an incredible , dferent shows across  venues, has come top in a newly-ranked list of the  ldquomost memorable, surprising and compelling experiences, compiled by Lonely Planet.The Fringe earned its place at the top spot because, according to the travel guide publisher, it ldquofloods the city with art, and nowhere beats it for spectacle or scale.Read more:Why I love living in Edinburgh at Festival timeA snippet of its entry reads: ldquoWhatever the time of day, an acrobat, trapeze artist, contortionist or tried-and-tested bagpiping busker will be pleased to entertain you. Simply step through the looking glass and prepare to be dazzled by the greatest show of arts and culture on Earth.The British Museum, described as ldquothe envy of the world, came in second, with the ldquotimeless and unrepeatable Giantrsquos Causeway in Northern Ireland concluding the top three.There are two other Scottish entries in the top  ndash Glencoe in is th place, while Arthurrsquos Seat in Edinburgh ranks th ndash while no fewer than  of the countryrsquos attractions made the complete list of , including the North Coast  , Skyersquos Fairy Poolsand Shetlandrsquos annual Viking celebration Up Helly Aa Shona McCarthy, chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society, last night described the accolade as a ldquotrue testament to the creativity, energy and imagination that Fringe artists and audiences bring to Edinburgh each year.She added: What makes the Fringe so special is that everyone with a story to tell is welcome, and with a record  countries represented on stage this year and nearly , shows from Scotland, this yearrsquos festival is playing host to a truly unique combination of homegrown and international talent. The Fringe is a real celebration of Edinburgh and the people that make it.For the first time, attractions in the UKrsquos four constituent countries were ranked in order of their brilliance to create the Ultimate United Kingdom Travelist.The mammoth list was compiled after Lonely Planet painstakingly listed every highlight from the UK guidebooks. Every sight, tourist attraction and appearance that captured their writersrsquo attention over the years were included.Staff based at the firmrsquos London HQ, alongside  leading figures in the countryrsquos travel sector, were asked to reveal their favourite spots and experiences before voting began. With hundreds of votes cast, each of the  experiences were given a score.Read more: must-see shows at the Edinburgh festivals this weekldquoLonely Planetrsquos Ultimate United Kingdom Travelist brings together the UKrsquos most compelling sights and experiences, ranging from world-class museums and giant cathedrals to rollicking festivals, inky lochs and tiny pubs, the companyrsquos Tom Hall explained. ldquoWersquore thrilled to name the worldrsquos largest arts festival, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the UKrsquos top experience. Itrsquos one of the most exciting and erse destinations on the planet.Scotlandrsquos contributions to the new travel guide also delighted tourism bosses.Malcolm Roughead, chief executive of national tourist agency VisitScotland, said: ldquoScotland is home to many amazing experiences so itrsquos no surprise they feature prominently in Lonely Planetrsquos Ultimate United Kingdom Travelist. They are year-round activities that traverse theand breadth of the country and we hope the guide will prove a catalyst for visitors to get out and explore the regions and create unique and thrilling experiences of their own.He added: ldquoTourism is vital to the Scottish economy, reaching every corner of the country, creating jobs and bringing economic and social change. Accolades like this highlight Scotland as a world-class destination however it is imperative that we donrsquot become complacent. We need to continue to create must-see experiences, events and attractions that continue to inspire travellers and keep up with the ever-changing demands of visitors.

title: win-no-voter-economy-stupid
story: It may be that living here, now, in our identity-dominated politics, repels me. It may be the low quality of our petty, patronising political discourse at Scottish, UK and EU level. Or it may be the cringe I feel when I hear that the NHS or the education system or whatever  is the ldquoenvy of the world, with all available evidence suggesting the contrary.Either way, Irsquom not exercised by national identity. My political decisions are made clinically. I am emotionally cold to political parties and to the sides of a referendum campaign. I cast my vote based purely on the perceived risk and reward for me and my family.:UK first in line for trade deal post Brexit, insists US security chief John BoltonAll of this is to make clear that, whilst I may not win a Patriot of the Year award, I am not uncomfortable with the theory of living in an independent Scotland. But in rsquos independence referendum my risk reward matrix led me to vote No. In truth, it was not a dficult choice. I have never doubted the long-term viability of an independent Scotland, but in the short-term I saw a fiscal hole with a policy  which would have made it bigger, not smaller. Too much risk, not enough reward.My choice was not an unusual one it is generally accepted through subsequent polling that uncertainty over the economic case was the central inhibitor to pushing the Yes campaign over the  per cent line.The prospect of a second independence referendum is now real. The  Scottish election is the most important in devolutionrsquos short history. The campaign will be, as good as, single-issue: should there or should there not be another referendum  If the pro-independence partiesa Holyrood majority, based on a clear, unambiguous and identical manesto pledge, then indyref  is in my view a democratic requirement. This is, effectively, the point acknowledged by both John McDonnell and David Mundell last week.How could Yes win  First, it could double-down on the - ldquocampaign ndash tack to the left, promote populist economics, arrange a big march, wave some Palestinian flags, Bairns Not Bombs, End London Rule and all the rest.Perhaps we are in an era where this can work. The recent record of prevailing economic theory winning political arguments is murky. The Yes campaign in  almost won despite the economic orthodoxy running contrary, as did Jeremy Corbyn in , and in , of course, the Leave campaign proved that relentless economic warnings can be ignored by a majority of the population.However this ndash a win based on a socialist fairytale ndash is no way to create a new country. We can damn private enterprise, wealth creators and taxpayers, but without them wersquoll find ourselves at the bottom of a social and economic pit in short order. This is student union politics, and high school economics. Eventhey could win this way, they shouldnrsquot.I spend most days with the Scottish business community. Their world is ruled by risk. And although, of course, this ies industry-to-industry, they generally see three primary political risks affecting their business. The first, and most concerning for them, is a Corbyn-led Labour government, the second is Scottish independence and the third is Brexit. Yes campaigners may wish that this order was radically altered, but that is the reality on the ground.:Mark Smith: How a Wings Over Scotland party could turn Yes to NoMost people in business ndash generally Remainers, generally No voters ndash are miles away from voting Yes, and every time they see the marchers and their flags and their populism on a Saturday afternoon, they move still further. They want to see some adults in the room.It is not as though the SNP doesnrsquot understand this. Andrew Wilsonrsquos Growth Commission was an effort to reassure this key demographic. And it was a very good one, primarily, in my view, because it acknowledged the economic reality of a small country in a big world, and did not bow to populism .But the Wilson report is one of very few items on that side of the balancing scale, still sitting high in the air, weighed down by the cacophony of evidence that the economic argument has not evolved.The SNP needs a long runway to prove that an independent Scotland can be an economic success story. There are a couple of obvious hurdles along the way. The first will come later this year, with the Scottish Governmentrsquos annual Budget. Since the  election ed a minority government, the SNP has relied on Green support for three budgets in a row. Each one has involved further concessions each one has pulled the SNP further left, particularly on tax. Not a lot just a little each time. The  budget will do the same.With the backdrop of a Boris Johnson government which might lower personal taxes in England, an expanding gap between Scottish and English taxpayers will really start to bite. Scots donrsquot like paying taxes any more than anyone  attempts to argue the contrary are delusional.The second hurdle is,anything, more dficult to tackle. Over the coming weeks, Westminster mathematics may present the SNP with an opportunity to replace Boris Johnson with Jeremy Corbyn infor a second independence referendum. This will be tempting. Indeed, it will likely be impossible to resist, and I am not suggesting that it should be.:Marianne Taylor: Gordon Brown insults us all by claiming independence is an evilHowever, this action would have a consequence. As the leaders of the past, current and future Yes campaign, the SNP is responsible for creating that sensible economic narrative. Where does putting Mr Corbyn into Downing Street fit into it The Yes campaign needs to build economic competence. From scratch. Partly because it will help it win. But primarily becausewersquore going to be an independent country, then we need to be a grown-up country. We all need to live here, after all.Read more: Brexit has opened a gap in Scottish politics for a new Tony Blair

title: pensioner-dentures-throat-eight-days-surgery
story: The -year-old anonymous man had an operation at an unnamed hospital to remove a harmless lump in his abdominal wall, but six days later had toto AE.He complained of blood in his mouth, swallowing dficulties and pain, which had prevented him from eating solid food, according to the report in the BMJ Case Reports medical journal.The man was sent home and prescribed mouthwash, antibiotics and steroids to treat what doctors thought were the effects of having a tube down his throat during surgery and a respiratory infection.:Glasgow girl, , becomes youngest ever to get deep-brain surgeryBut, two days later, the retired electrician ed to AE with worsening symptoms ndash unable to swallow any of the medicine he was admitted with suspected pneumonia.Doctors then discovered he had a semi-circular object lying across his vocal chords, which had caused internal swelling and blistering.The report states: ldquoOn explaining this to the patient, he revealed that his dentures had been lost during his general surgery admission eight days earlier and consisted of a metallic roof plate and three front teeth.:Twins joined at head successfully separated in London hospital opX-rays confirmed this was the foreign body lodged in his throat ndash he was taken for emergency surgery to remove them and discharged after six days in hospital.However, a bout of bleeding forced him toonce more six days later, followed by a second visit  days after that, and a third six days after being discharged again.Tests showed he had suffered an internal wound tissue around the site of the blistering which doctors then treated by cauterising it to prevent further bleeding.The man also required a blood transfusion because he had lost so much blood.But his ordeal was far from over.Nine days after he was discharged once more, he ed with further bleeding which required emergency surgery as the source of the bleed was a torn artery in the wound.According to the report, a check-up a week after the procedure showed the tissue was healing, and six weeks after that the man had not needed further emergency care.However, the authors of the report state that this is not the first instance of dentures being inhaled while anaesthetic is being administered.:Art competition win for teenager who lost her right arm in bone cancer battle#ldquoThere are no set national guidelines on how dentures should be managed during anaesthesia, but it is known that leaving dentures in during bag-mask ventilation allows for a better seal during induction, and therefore, many hospitals allow dentures to be removed immediately before intubation, as long as this is clearly documented, the report adds.According to the authors, learning points from the incident include clearly documenting before and after any procedure the presence of any dentures or  teeth, with all members of the surgical team made aware of what is to be done with them.

title: uk-39-first-line-39-trade-deal-post-brexit-insists-us-security-chief-john-bolton
story: ldquoWe are with you, he declared after discussing not only Brexit but also Iran, Hong Kong as well as Huawei and G with BorisJohnson and senior Cabinet ministers andofficials.Following the meeting, Mr Bolton, one of the Presidentrsquos closest advisers, suggested that a US-UK trade agreement could be done on a gradual ldquosector by sector basis, starting with manufacturing and car-making where the two countries might easily seal agreements and working out more complicated areas later on.He brushed aside concerns that Congress could block a trade deal over the consequences a no-deal Brexit could have on Ireland.:Pound es against euro and dollar on Brexit fearMr Boltonrsquos declaration on a future trade deal came as pollsters suggested a majority of the British public think Mr Johnson should suspend Parliament in order to push through Brexit.Following his Downing St meeting, Mr Bolton said: "The main purpose of the visit really is to convey President Trumps desire to see a successful exit from the European Union for the United Kingdom on October , to offer to be of help in any way that we can and to express his hope we can have a fully comprehensive bilateral trade agreement with the United Kingdom as soon as possible."He added: "To be clear, in the Trump administration, Britains constantly at the front of the trade queue, or line as we say."This contrasted with the famous line from Barack Obama, the previous President, who, in the run-up to the EU referendum, suggested thatBritain left the EU it would be at the back of the queue in terms of a trade deal.Mr Bolton said the US could do a trade deal with the UK "in pieces" and concentrate on areas, like manufacturing and the car-making industry, they can agree on first."You could do it sector by sector, you could do it in a modular fashion in other words. You could carve out some areas where it might be possible to reach a bilateral agreement very quickly, very straightforwardly."That would then lock that in and when the other areas that might be more dficult were concluded later, you could combine it in one overall agreement. So, the objective is either one document or a series of agreements that would be comprehensive."In order to expedite things and enhance the possibility for increasing the trade and investments between the two countries, doing it in a sector-by-sector approach or some other approach that the trade negotiators might agree with, we are open to that.":Scots face paying out millions to nationalise shipyardHe added: "The idea of doing it in pieces rather than waiting for the whole thing is not unprecedented. Here we see the importance and urgency of doing as much as we can agree on as rapidly as possible because of the impending October  exit date."Asked whether piecemeal trade agreements like this are allowed under World Trade Organisation rules, Mr Bolton said: "Our trade negotiators seem to think it is."Camleys cartoon: Johnson braced for tough US trade talksThe national security adviser also attacked the EU and said the UKs decision to leave the EU should be respected."We see a successful exit as being very much in our interests. Britainrsquos success in exiting the EU is a statement about democratic rule. The fashion in the European Union when the people vote the wrong way from the way that the elites want to go, is to make the peasants vote again and again until they get it right.": We must resist Boris Johnson by any means necessary or its goodnight democracyMr Boltons remarks came as a new ComRes poll for The Dailyfound  per cent of the public agreed that the Prime Minister"needs to deliver Brexit by any means, including suspending Parliamentnecessary, in order to prevent MPs from stopping it".Many MPs have expressed outrage at the idea of proroguing Parliament in order to avoid a no-deal scenario being halted by the Commons.The poll of , British adults also, however, found  per cent of respondents agreed that "Brexit should be haltedproblems over the Northern Ireland border threaten to split the Union".According to the figures,  per cent of respondents felt Parliament was "out of touch" with the British public and  per cent felt MPs "ignore the wishes of voters and push their own agendas" on Brexit.

title: alex-salmond-receives-500-000-expenses-payout-scottish-government
story: In January , Mr Salmond was accused ofinappropriate behaviourand an internal investigation was carried out by officials.However, the former First Minister went on to launcha judicial review into the way the probe was carried out and the government wasforced to admit it had breached guidelinesby appointing an investigating officer who had "prior involvement".Ministers have now confirmed that they have paid the substantial settlement for his expensesin the case.A Scottish Government spokesman said today: ldquoWe can confirm that final settlement of pound, has been made to Mr Salmond for legal costs arising from his petition for judicial review.MSPs at Holyrood have established an inquiry into what went wrong with the Scottish Governments probe, but it has been suspended until acriminal case against Mr Salmond concludes.Despite this, oppositionMSPs have now stepped up calls for Holyrood to "get to the bottom" of the failed investigation.Scottish Conservative MSP, and member of the Committee on the Scottish Government Handling of Harassment Complaints, Donald Cameron said: ldquoIt is outrageous that over half a million pounds has been wasted thanks to the botched handling of this investigation.ldquoThis is taxpayersrsquo money that will be handed over to Alex Salmond thanks to the appalling way these complaints were dealt with."The payout also came under fire from Liberal Democrat MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton.ldquoParliament will have to get to the bottom of this expensive and flawed inquiry, he said.Following a separate policeinvestigation, Mr Salmond was subsequently charged with with a string of sexual offences which he denies.

title: new-youth-project-researches-impact-climate-change-coast
story: The On Our Wave Length initiative will see teams of young people from Argyll and Bute, Fe, North Berwick, South Ayrshire and the Western Isles investigate environmental consequences on beaches and waters of their local coasts.The partnership between YouthLink Scotland and Traditional Arts and Culture Scotland, funded by the National Lottery Heritage Fund, will pair the Young Heritage Researchers with youth workers to assist in their findings.Experts from Scottish Natural Heritage and Scottish Coastal Archeology and the Problem of Erosionwill also be on hand to help.:Youth climate strikes: Show the world we stand up for planet EarthThe young people will be encouraged to set their own research parameters and explore issues that matter most to them and their communities from climate breakdown, industry pollution and the impact on wildle and oceans.Amy Calder, Senior Policy and Research Officer, YouthLink Scotland said:"Watching Greta Thunberg and young people across the world marching through the streets to fight for a sustainable future, showing adults that climate change is real and needs tackling now, has been extremely inspiring."It also highlights the power of youth voice in holding adults to account for actions that will affect them and future generations."Early next year the project will launch a youth-led national campaign to highlight the damaging environmental and and social impacts on sea-side communities.The initiative launches at the beginning of the Year of Coasts and Waters  where Scotlands waters will be celebrated with a programme of activity designed to inspire both visitors and locals to explore and experience the countrys unrivalled shores.Well established annual festivities such as the Scottish Traditional Boat Festival at Portsoy and Crail Food Festival will be joined by The Fe Regatta, an expanded Clydebuilt Festival, and Edinburgh International Film Festival will present Scotlands Shores, featuring classic film screenings and a special outdoor coastal experience.The RSPB will celebrate Aberdeens status as one of the few cities in Europe where dolphins can regularly be seen from the shore at DolphinFest . Scotlands Boat Show and Kip Marina will make a splash with a brand new special event River of Light and The National Theatre of Scotland will deliver, Ferry Tales, an exciting new production, celebrating Scotlands surrounding waters and the journeys over them made by thousands of residents and tourists.For young people from the North Berwick Youth Project, who are involved in the On Our Wave Length initiative, the project will help them to investigate already existing concerns they have about their area, says project director, Lesley Kay.She said: "Young people are passionately interested in environmental issues and itrsquos fantastic that through this new project, they will be supported by youth workers and environmentalists to investigate the impacts of pollution and global warming right on their doorstep."As a coastal community there are a iety of environmental consequences for young people to consider, including coastal erosion, the predicted rise in sea levels, the need for marine conservation in the light of climate change and the effect of litter, in particular single use plastics."The findings of the Young Heritage Researchers will be shared at a national event in the Storytelling Centre in Edinburgh in July , and then local story-sharing events in their communities.Ms Calder said: "Itrsquos fitting the research report is unveiled at the centre, as it is through the stories of first-hand accounts of damage to our coasts and waters that will bring communities together to fight against climate change."The On Our Wave Length project is another vital investment in understanding the impact of climate change and joins other projects in Scotland such as the beneficiaries of the latest round of Scottish Natural Heritage rsquos Green Infrastructure Fund, launched in .Nearly pound million of funding has been made available to help reduce the impacts of climate crisis in urban areas across the Central Belt.:Lack of funding for farmers looking to recycle plasticThe fund aims to tackle socio-economic issues such as poor health and high unemployment by creating and improving greenspaces in communities as well as attempting to mitigate effects of global climate change.The seven latest projects will improve habitats and bioersity, transform unused land, tackle flood risk and create new active travel routes, community gardens and play areas in Glasgow, Bishopbriggs and Dunfermline.SNH Chief Executive Francesca Osowska said: ldquoWe know that connecting people with nature makes them happier and healthier and itrsquos great to see this funding delivering that in our most deprived areas.ldquoIn addition to the many social and economic benefits, improving our urban greenspace can also help us adapt to and mitigate climate change.ldquoThis funding will help us create a nature-rich future for everyone in Scotland, part of the solution to the climate emergency facing us all.The EU-backed Green Infrastructure Fund is part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos European Regional Development Fundprogramme and is being delivered in two phases.Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said: ldquoThis investment will bring signicant benefits to communities across seven more urban areas, repurposing and revitalising land to create green spaces and infrastructure.ldquoCrucially, this funding will also help address the impacts of climate change by improving bioersity, managing flood risk, and reducing pollution, while promoting new low carbon lestyle choices and active transport options in the heart of our communities.

title: scotland-found-uk-mobile-phone-offence-hotspot
story: The transport select committee has said using any type of mobile phone while driving had potentially catastrophic consequences and warned that current laws give the "misleading impression" that hands-free options are safe.And the MPs called for more severe penalties ldquocommensurate with the risks, as road deaths linked to phone use have risen steadily over the past decade.A public consultation on the proposal should be published by the end of , the cross-party group said.It is understood the Scottish Government would support a ban on hands-free mobile phones from a road safety point of view as long as the proposal is backed with evidence and proper impact assessments.It comes as it emerged research found that Scotland is a UK hotspot for distracted driving offences.Court penalties doubled when tough mobile phone driving laws were introduced in March, .And research using freedom of legislation carried out for the motor dealers Peter Vardy revealed that in around nine months after the new legislation, there had been , recorded offences since March across  constabularies in the UK.Scotland was said to have been the worst region, accounting for , of these.A separate survey at around the same time to determine the places that are the worst offenders found that came top with nearly three in four admitting to using their phones behind the wheel. This was closely followed by London where % said they used their phones while driving, as did % of Glaswegians, % in Cardf and % of Birmingham drivers.The safest place for other drivers and pedestrians appears to be Southampton, where just one in twenty of drivers admitted to using their phones. While people in Bristol , Manchesterand Nottinghammade up the four lowest cities for mobile phone use behind the wheel.:Lorry driver caught checking his phone before fatal crash jailed for five yearsIn September, last year, -year-old recovery driver David Shields who was caught on camera checking his phone prior to a fatal crash was jailed for five years.The driver crashed into -year-old Yvonne Blackmans car in a line of traffic on the A in Dumfries last February.He had previously admitted a charge of causing the mother-of-fours death by dangerous driving.Footage captured Shields, of Drongan, East Ayrshire, focusing on his phone for a full  seconds in the lead-up to the fatal crash.Brake, the road safety charity said research showed using a hands-free phone can impair a driver in the same way as a hand-held device and so it makes sense that the law treats these acts equally.A Brake spokesman said: ldquoThe number of distracted driving offences in Scotland is cause for concern and highlights that there is still much work to be done regarding the dangers of phone use behind the wheel.:Time to ban phones in schools: Cross-party MSPs call for Holyrood investigationldquoWe need urgent clarication of the law on using hand-held mobile devices while driving, including closing loopholes which treat sending or receiving data dferently."The current law also provides a dangerous  impression that it is safe to use a mobile phone with a hands-free kit - it is not. All phone use behind the wheel is dangerous, and we need the law to reflect this by banning the use of hands-free devices."It is also true that a law is only as strong as its enforcement and so we want to see further resources provided to the police to make sure there is an effective deterrent to the menace of mobile phone use behind the wheel.A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoWhile the power to legislate in this area is reserved to the UK Government, we are clear that road safety is a priority and we recognise that driving while distracted puts the driver and other road users at greater risk.ldquoWe continue to support behavioural change and marketing campaigns through Road Safety Scotland. The message from us and all road safety partners is clear - do not risk your safety or the safety of others by using a mobile phone behind the wheel of a car.

title: tennents-maps-scotlands-top-15-pubs-view
story: A new guide to Scotlands most scenic pubs has been launched in a bit to introduce beerlovers to a pint with a view.But anyone wishing to finish the trek will have to get their walking boots on and have some time to spare , as it criss-crosses the country for  miles by land and sea and none of the bars are exactly local.However, when they have called last orders on the mammoth trip, they will have visited some of Scotlands most stand-out hostelries, including a -year-old coaching inn, a pint aboard a boat on Loch Katrine and a bar located within the stunning glens of the Cairngorms National Park.The map was Tennents ideaThe lsquoViewPintsrsquo map, celebrates  pubs and bars across the country with the most spectacular views as judged by brewers Tennants - who are offering a years supply of beer to the first five people to complete the pint pilgrimage:Scottish snorkel trail unveiledStarting points are down do the inidual drinkers - butone were to pick the most northerly pub, theyd be supping their first ale in the restful surroundings of the Cullen Bar Hotel on the Moray Coast.The coastline - named by National Geographic magazine as one of the most beautul in the world - is a prime spot for watching dolphins, and the hotel boasts a cozy corner from which to watch the seaborne mammals at play.The next step south sees travellers spot dolphin-gazing for monster swapping, with a stop at the Clansman Hotel, the only hotel on the banks of Loch Ness.After a swt pint there, its onto the West Highlands for a snter at the centuries-old Arisaig Hotel on the banks of Loch nan Ceall, which is said to date back to Jacobean times.Boasting views of the Lochs white sand beaches, the drinking spot is the most westerly stop on the mainland.Jura is one of the stops on the crawlAfter that, the crawl south heads to the Macdonald Hotel in Kinlochleven, where a pint can be enjoyed while taking in the breathtaking surroundings of Loch Leven, and then on to Forbes of Kingennie country resort and the Glen Cova Hotel in Angus, where four glens can be viewed at once.After that,any intrepid drinkers are still standing, a choice has to be made - either head for the Central Belt and the south, or out to the islands.:Tourism boost as Fe Pilgrim Way re-opens#Those attempting to complete the crawl will have to cross the sea to Jura - where they can enjoy a pint with a half of the islands famous malt while stags walk past the window of the Jura Hotel - and also make the trip to Arran for a stop at the Douglas Hotel, which wins its place on the map thanks to its unrivalled views of Brodick Bay.The trail of beers then makes its way across to the Kintyre peninsula for a drink at the Argyll Hotel in Cambeltown, where the sea laps almost to the door.Heading back east, the crawl takes in another water-based journey with a tipple aboard the Sir Walter Scott steam cruise ship on Loch Katrine, before hitting the road towards Glasgow and swinging by Tennents own Wellpark Brewery.As is the Wellpark Brewery in GlasgowThe east coast segment sees drinkers ensconced in the cozy surroundings of the The Boat Brae at Newport on Tay, whose windows feature panoramic views of the iconic river.And no trip around Scotland would be complete without a visit to the East Neuk of Fe, where the crawl visits with a stop at the St Andrews Holiday Park.Here, the view is of the towns sandy bay, with the ancient ruined Cathedral as a backdrop.:Basking shark tour firms gets top awardFamed as the home of golf, the towns ancient buildings and picturesque streets have been charming people for hundreds of years, while the Fe Coastal Path, which passes alongside the park taking in rugged clfs, long sandy beaches and wildle reserves, provides those on the crawl with the option to stagger some of the way on to their next destination.Overlooking the majestic South Queensferry Crossing, Scotts Bar  Restaurant in South Queensferry boasts the most up-to-date view, taking in Scotlands latest engineering marvel.And then the crawl comes to an end with a trip to the Royal Mile Tavern in Edinburgh, where the scenery is the heart of the capitals historic Old Town.The map is a tour of ScotlandAlan McGarrie, Group Brand Director for Tennentrsquos Lager, said completing the crawl would give participants a fresh taste of Scotand.He said: ldquoScotland is the most beautul country in the world, and what better way to compliment those stunning views than with a pint of the countryrsquos favourite beer."Wersquove created the ViewPints map to inspire and challenge beer drinkers to get out and see Scotland like never before."Taking in all of the bars would be a very impressive achievement, which is why therersquos a yearrsquos supply of beer for anyone who manages to make it round all .

title: dougie-mclean-reveals-plans-caledonia---musical
story: But now Dougie MacLean is adding to his world-famous repertoire of hit singles, movie scores, live music extravaganzas and festivals ndash by taking perhaps his best-loved work to the stage with ldquoCaledonia ndash The Musical.ldquoItrsquos a musical ndash Irsquom in the middle of working on it, he smiles. ldquoCaledonia ndash The Musical. Itrsquos just something that I wanted to do. But these guys worked out how to do it.ldquoThe concert is more of a solo concert with me touching my cap to the piping tradition. Irsquove always liked to use whistles and bagpipes, rather that saxophones ndash because they are Scottish.MacLean says Scotland is in rude health, culturally, shaking off the stereotypical caricature of the Harry Lauder years, adding: ldquoTherersquos a lovely, modern, sophisticated image that we have now and Irsquod like to think Irsquove been part of that whole cultural revolution that began to happen around  years ago.Next month he turns , but he laughs: ldquoIrsquom busier this year than Irsquove ever been. As long as Irsquove got a voice and I can drive and travel, Irsquoll keep on doing it.Dougie MacLean performs at the Glasgow Royal Concert Hall this Sunday, .pm, for Piping Live!

title: Rosemary Goring  Do not pine for old-style neighbourly spirit - it didn t really exist
story: One historian, however, has challenged this gloomy view. Professor Jon Lawrence, of the University of Exeter, is the author of the recently published history, Me, Me, Me  The Search for Community in Post-War England. Comparing how people interacted in the past with how we behave today, he believes Facebook et al offer great opportunities for engaging meaningfully with others. Thanks to this technology, iniduals can make and sustain relationships with those they choose to befriend, rather than being obliged to fit into the community in which they happen to live or indeed work.While Lawrence is optimistic about the potential of social media, he also dispels the myth of a ldquogolden age of tight-knit communities our grandparents were familiar with. After analysing hundreds of post-war interviews with those living in working-class districts, middle-class towns, inner cities and suburbs, he believes that rather than a positive and nurturing environment, these were often a source of deep tension and conflict. His conclusion is that our reverence for the bonds of those living cheek by jowl in bygone years, when compared with our own inidualistic and self-centred age, is misplaced. As he writes, ldquoCommunity hasnrsquot died, but it has changed.Perhaps Irsquom just cynical, but whenever I hear the phrase ldquotight-knit community, I picture not a happy, supportive parish eager to take soup to the ill or babysit at short notice, but a simmering cauldron of gossip and backbiting. Such a seemingly cosy set-up is a staple ingredient for writers of soporic crime fiction ndash reaching its apotheosis in Midsomer Murders ndash where the chocolate box rural idyll, or the charming Hovis street scene, is revealed as a snakepit. Everyone, it seems, including the postman nursed a grievance against the poor soul felled by a scone laced with weedkiller. How  to explain the advent of soap operas like Coronation Street and, ahem, Neighbours,proximity to others created universal joy Only those who have never shared a roof with strangers, be it a tenement flat or rented room, are blinkered enough to be nostalgic about what itrsquos like to live within constant earshot of someonersquos Benson and Hedges death rattle. Molly Weir helped immortalise the idea of the essentially kind-hearted collegiate spirit of living like sardines with her amusing memoirs of le in a Springburn tenement. One scene in particular sticks with me, as she describes the way in which women doing their washing in the basement wash-house at night-time would soap and scrub by flickering candlelight, urged on by onlookers offering advice.But yoursquoll find a dferent portrait altogether in fellow Glaswegian Agnes Muirheadrsquos recollections from around . After someone next door lit a coal fire on wash day, meaning her motherrsquos laundry had to be taken in and done again, she took action. When the culpritrsquos own washing was hung out to dry, Muirhead carried out the ash bins and accidentally knocked into the clean clothes and sheets: ldquoSo that stopped that. We put an end tae that.Even the best of neighbours can create frictiontheir fondness for heavy metal is indulged loudly at an antisocial hour, or their teenagers hold a party when they are away. But you donrsquot need to be living through a thin wall for arguments to arise. Even before the arrival of Leylandii there have been stories of garden battles over hedges and trees, sometimes spilling into violence and occasionally ndash back to Midsomer Murders ndash homicidal rage.Yet despite its many pitfalls, the idea of living in companionable harmony with those in the same street or hamlet is appealing, and in some places still quite common. This is in part probably because cars allow much greater mobility, and nobody need feel trapped. And while social media makes it possible not to lose touch with distant friends and relatives, you canrsquot help feeling that eventhis offers a sense of companionship ndash as in the old days did a long catch-up phone call ndash it is no substitute for meeting in person. By the time yoursquove got a job and perhaps a family of your own, how many true friends, as opposed to online friends, can you really keep close to The evolutionary anthropologist Robin Dunbar thinks that humans are hardwired to enjoy a meaningful relationship with no more than  others. That was the average size of the traditional village, he says, and is what our brain has evolved to cope with and process comfortably. So those with thousands of online friends or followers might feel proud of their popularity, but to some extent you could call this an illusion. Dunbar is also certain that face-to-face encounters far outstrip online contact as a demonstration of friendship, connection and reassurance that actively makes us feel liked and happy.None of this is particularly surprising. We all instinctively know our limits, and have invisible inner and outer circles of friends and acquaintances. Nor should handwringing about the decline of old-style neighbourliness among those of us who would still rather post a card than an online message come as any surprise. Upcoming generations have always found new ways to communicate and connect. None of them is perfect, sadly, and as in every realm of human interaction, all bring problems as well as pleasures. What is clear, though, is that whether itrsquos in a tenement close, or a Hebridean clachan, whether you live in a gated community or on a picturesque village green, like it or not, we all depend on other people, and have an obligation to them. This applies to everyone, whether they are within shooting distance, or connected only by wi.Read more: Time to abandon the tourist hotspots

title: nora-quoirins-family-say-teenager-touched-world
story: In an emotional statement, the devastated family also offered their thanks to those involved in the search for the -year-old.A post-mortem is due to take place on Wednesday to determine Norarsquos cause of death.Her body was discovered beside a small stream, about . kilometresfrom the jungle resort of Dusun, on Tuesday.:Nora Quoirin -Body found in Malaysia identied as missing teenagerDescribing how the teenager had ldquotruly touched the world, her family said: ldquoNora is at the heart of our family. She is the truest, most precious girl and we love her infinitely.ldquoThe cruelty of her being taken away is unbearable. Our hearts are broken.ldquoWe will always love our Nora.The statement added: ldquoWe would like to thank all the people that have been searching for Nora and trying their best to find her.ldquoWe thank the local people here and those far and wide for their prayers and support at this time.ldquoNora has brought people together, especially from France, Ireland, Britain and Malaysia, united in their love and support for her and her family.ldquoTo all our friends and family at home, we canrsquot thank you enough for all your love.Nora, who was born with the brain defect holoprosencephaly, disappeared on Sunday August  while on holiday with her family.:Parents of missing British girl thank Malaysian search operation teamsHundreds of people were involved in the search and rescue operation and it was volunteer helpers who found her body.Deputy police chief Mazlan Mansor told reporters at a press conference that the remains were winched by helicopter to a hospital mortuary.He added thatthe body ldquowas not in any clothings and that while it remained a missing persons case police werelooking into all possibilities including the ldquoangle of criminal investigation.The teenagerrsquos parents, Meabh and Sebastien Quoirin, a French-Irish couple who have lived in London for  years, had thanked those looking for her as fundraising pages set up by Norarsquos aunt and uncle collected more than pound, from well-wishers.Following the confirmation that Norarsquos body had been found, Irish premier Leo Varadkar said that the situation was ldquoevery familyrsquos worst nightmare.He tweeted: ldquoOur thoughts  sincere condolences are with Nora Quoirinrsquos parents, siblings  wider family at this unimaginably dficult time.ldquoThey have experienced every familyrsquos worst nightmare. Irsquod like to pay tribute to everyone who searched for Nora. May she rest in peace.:Search continues for London girl missing in MalaysiaPresident of Ireland, Michael D Higgins, and his we Sabina offered their ldquodeepest condolences to Norarsquos parents, to her siblings and to her extended family.The French Foreign Ministry also expressed its sincere condolences to Norarsquos family.Our thoughts  sincere condolences are with Noacutera Quoirinrsquos parents, siblings  wider family at this unimaginably dficult time. They have experienced every familyrsquos worst nightmare. Irsquod like to pay tribute to everyone who searched for Nora. May she rest in peace.mdash Leo VaradkarAugust , The Quoirins had said Norarsquos condition meant she was not independent and had dficulty walking.Search crews looking for the teenager had played her motherrsquos voice in the dense Malaysian forest near where she disappeared.Police had said Nora who was travelling on an Irish passport, was believed to have climbed out of her resort room window.After Nora went missing, her family described how she was particularly vulnerable.Describing her as a ldquovery special person, they said she would not have goneanywhere alone.

title: firstgroup-take-west-coast-main-line
story: The firm said the route would pave the way for an era of high speed rail, and is due to take over in December as part of a consortium with Italian company Trenitalia.First Trenitalia replaces Virgin Trains, which was barred from bidding to keep the route.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the bid was part of a sht to a new model for rail, but Unions have criticised the move - saying Westminster was taking "yet another gamble".Mr Shapps said the partnership was supported by Keith Williams, who has been commissioned to look at changes to the rail franchising system and has told the BBC that government involvement should be limited to overall policy and budget decisions.Virgin Trains has run the route since "This award is positive news for passengers with more services, more system."Meeting Keith last week confirmed our shared determination to deliver a future that puts passengers at the heart of the railways, and get our trains to run on time.:Travel delays on West Coast title: dougie-maclean-scottish-independence-caledonia-piping-live
story: :Dougie MacLean reveals plans for Caledonia - The MusicalDOUGIE MACLEAN AND CALEDONIA ndash THE STORY OF A SONGCaledonia was a homesick song. I was on a beach in Brittany, France. I finished it and was staying in a youth hostel with three friends who were from Ireland, we were busking basically in the streets around France.Wersquod jump on a train basically, see a nice town and get off, did a few wee gigs and I finished the song off.I remember going back to the youth hostel where we were staying, singing it to them, we were all that homesick anyway we left the next day. I went back with then to Northern Ireland and the first time I sang it basically was at a party outside Belfast somewhere.The first time I ever performed it on stage was in West Berlin. Irsquod gone back to Germany and was touring around and I didnrsquot do many of my own songs at that time, I did a lot more traditional songs, a bit of fiddle, and I snuck this song in and the audience just loved it.Even a way back then, I was  maybe, I turned around and said wersquoll keep that in the set.Caledonia is only a tiny, little part of what I do.But therersquos something about Caledonia that became part of common culture which is fascinating and which is a great thrill for a songwriter to have something that is part of common culture ndash that is sung at football games, played at Scottish weddings, is played at funerals, you hear buskers singing it in the streets.I have incredible stories about Caledonia, you canrsquot invent that.People have tried to make anthemic songs ndash and they donrsquot work. People choose their own anthemic songs, and I donrsquot know why Caledonia has seeped into this.Therersquos probably not a night goes by and therersquos not a drunk standing somewhere singing Caledonia.DOUGIE MACLEAN ON THE MEANING BEHIND CALEDONIAWhen you are young, you donrsquot have the baggage of le so you are a wee bit more honest in what you say and in what you write.I mean, I was just really very homesick and I wrote what was there.If I tried to write it now, I probably couldnrsquot, because I would be saying lsquooh no, thatrsquos too sentimentalrsquo or whatever.Caledonia is a big song over in Ireland, itrsquos a big song whenever Irsquom over in Europe, itrsquos about the sense of belonging that it has.It encapsulates your own sense of belonging, for me I would make it Scotland.But therersquos something  in that song that people identy with in terms of their own sense of belonging.I donrsquot know where it is today.Therersquos a lot of political turmoil, Irsquom not sure anybody knows how it will turn out. I try to sometimes to imagine whatrsquos going to happen, where itrsquos going to go, but I canrsquot.But I think having songs like Caledonia help people keep their cultural sense of identity, and an identity can be all-encompassing too.TURNING HIT SONG CALEDONIA INTO DOUGIE MACLEANrsquoS FIRST MUSICALItrsquos a musical - Irsquom in the middle of working on it. Caledonia the Musical. Itrsquos just something that I wanted to do.Irsquove been trying to keep it a bit of a secret, but Irsquove been enjoying the process of doing it.I wrote the script myself, I wrote the story, which is a nice thing to do at my stage of le after all these years as a travelling troubadour and songwriter.Irsquove got so many songs, there are  songs Irsquove written over the years and Irsquove got this great story ndash itrsquos a love story ndash and itrsquos cool.I was musical director years and years and years ago for TAG theatre company here in Glasgow at the Citizens Theatre for a three play series, A Scots Quair, and so I learned quite a lot in the process of being involved with that because we had music on stage as well.Irsquove been using a lot of what I learned there.I thought to myself, I know how this works, I can visualise a stage production Irsquom performing all the time for I know how audiences work, I know the songs that Irsquove written over the last  years and the ones that work on stage with people, so itrsquos great to just make a story and bring all those songs into that story.Itrsquos amazing that a song that I might have written for myself, thatyou put it in another situation, it changes the whole dynamic of the song.INFLUENCING SCOTLANDrsquoS CULTURAL IDENTITYScotland has a very modern vision of itself, a modern, progressive vision of its national identity which is kind of unusual.Irsquom glad that Scotland has developed it that way.Irsquom very proud of our Scottish Parliament, I think itrsquos very progressive and modern and I think Scotlandrsquos is a great international brand ndash people love Scotland, they love the whole concept of Scotland, I donrsquot know how politically it will all fold out because it gets very complicated.Itrsquos not a black and white thing anymore. There have been a lot of things ndash a lot of lies ndash said. People are maybe looking at ita bit more.Even culturally, Irsquove seen a huge dference in my letime the way that Scottish people identy themselves as Scottish.Back when we were kids we were embarrassed to be Scottish, it was that old buffoon with the wiggly stick and the hairy legs, the Harry Lauder caricature of being a Scot, but I think people arenrsquot anything like that ndash therersquos a lovely, modern, sophisticated image that we have now and our culturersquos been part of that.Irsquod like to think Irsquove been part of that whole cultural revolution that happened  years ago where it went away from being music hall to people writing their own stuff, we werenrsquot playing on the caricature of being Scottish, we were creating a fantastic cultural revolution ndash not just the folk guys, but the rock guys and everyone .DOUGIE MACLEAN ON SCOTTISH INDEPENDENCE AND EUROPEI think Scots are more confident in being Scottish, and maybe that will inevitably lead to independence.I donrsquot how that journey will go, but Irsquod like to see it myself because I believe in small things.I believe in independence, but part of a bigger thing.And itrsquos been like that in my own le, Irsquove been very independent in how Irsquove gone about things ndash I have my own company, my own studio, so I was in control of my own destiny.But without the bigger thing, it would be very dferent.Irsquom independent but in a big music scene. I think we need to be part of that bigger thing .:Dougie MacLean: lsquoI want people to be talking about Live by the Loch in next  yearsI think part of cultural identity is the brand, thatrsquos the glue thatkeeps the world together ndash everybody loves their cultural identity, andyou can invent one that encompasses and brings in other peoplersquos cultural identities too, then you have a modern Scotland that is quite dferent from the one that my dad would have imagined.Thatrsquos what makes my songs dferent from James Taylor songs because he writes them from an American perspective, but Irsquom not singing about traditional things, I write about human things.DOUGIE MACLEAN ON BEING A SCOTTISH MUSICAL PIONEERWhen we set up the record company, I built a wee recording studio, and nobody was doing it at the time. It was me and Ossian, another folk group, who were a great help.It was vinyl in these days, and you couldnrsquot get vinyl cut in Scotland, so I remember the first record I made up in Butterstone was a fiddle record and I had to get on an overnight Stagecoach to London, to Soho where they had the cutting rooms, with the master tapes under my arms, to get the vinyl cut on this thing.Thatrsquos where I learned that they used a diamond needle on the cutting machines, but they only used the new diamond needles for the big acts and when it was worn they put it on an old machine at the back and cut all the independents with it.People donrsquot realise thatrsquos how I did it.It was the early days of Stagecoach which is from Perthshire, and they had two old buses.The driver would stop halfway down, about Carlisle somewhere, and get this gin box out with his Thermos flask and come round to give everybody a cup of coffee and a sandwich that his we had made ndash that was it then, though Stagecoach are huge now of course.But thatrsquos how we had to do it.The CD has become devalued because it is so easy to make. But back then people said oh, yoursquoll never be able to do it, yoursquoll never be able to stay in Dunkeld, yoursquoll have to go to London, New York or even Glasgow or Edinburgh.But I was dogged, I said no, Irsquom going to stay here, and I made it.I live in my old school, the school that I went to, and my dad went to. Itrsquos a great story.I am on facetime a lot with my son Jamie who produces my records now, it all ties together. I like that. Itrsquos not an ego-driven lestyle, I keep bees, I collect Singer sewing machines, wersquore all surviving and itrsquos just our lives. Itrsquos what we do.TRYST AND DOUGIE MACLEAN PERFORMING AT PIPING LIVE! IN GLASGOWOne of the things about the TRYST concert, it was really nice of the guys to ask me to come along and be part of the Piping Live! Festival because I had a long history with bagpipes.I joined The Tannahill Weavers when I was , thatrsquos when that whole piping revolution was happening.I remember when the band Alba told us they getting their Highland bagpipes out, we were all ndash you cannae get your Highland bagpipes out in a folk ban,d because they were B flat and what have you.But these guys worked out how to do it and I ended up touring American with wee Alan on bagpipes, and I had my relationship with young Gordon Duncan who played on all my records when he was a youngster.This was all before it became really well established.The concert is more of a solo concert with me touching my cap to the piping tradition.I did a tour of America one time with Kathy Mattea who had just won a Grammy at the time, and she had come to my studio and we had recorded lsquoFrom a Distancersquo and Gordy had played a little bit of pipes on it for her.So when I went to America and did the special guest on her tour, she said lsquooh, I wish we could do that with the bagpipesrsquo so I learned the part of small pipes ndash it was the only part I could ever learn to play ndash and I walked onto the stage playing that. I felt a fraud.But I did it, Irsquom just hoping someone has a recording or photograph somewhere.DOUGIE MACLEAN ON PERFORMING IN GLASGOWI love Glasgow, I come down a lot. I did a solo show there recently which was brilliant and Irsquove done shows over the years, all the theatres around here and I worked at the Citizens.I remember coming down here as an eight-year-old, my uncle Roddy liked in Castlemilk, and coming down from where I lived up in Dunkeld, I might as well have been going to the moon.It was so dferent for me. I love living in the country, Irsquom a country boy, but I have very fond memories from Glasgow.Irsquove had great fun in Glasgow, with the festivals and the shows that Irsquove done ndash but a couple of night ago I played in Crieff, the night before that up in Findhorn on the north coast, and on Stornoway at An Laantair ndash it was fantastic.Irsquom a very positive person, I like all kinds of music, I like the creative process.The last couple of years Irsquove been doing solo concerts, Irsquove ed back to the essence of what I do.Irsquove done a lot of collaborating, Irsquove done orchestra stuff, with bands and things, but now Irsquom doing these shows solo and itrsquos great because I get this relationship with the audience going which you just canrsquot get in collaboration.I love that, I tell stories and get the audience to sing, I love that side of what I do.This weekendrsquos show at the Royal Concert Hall will be a bit like that, I donrsquot like formal concerts, itrsquos a Dougie Maclean concert with a bunch of my songs and a bunch of my stories and a bit of whistle here, a bit of bagpipes there, it is a great privilege to be asked to come down and be part of it.DOUGIE MACLEAN ON FILMING HIS LIFE STORYThe whole world is changing. I do a wee bit of photography and video.Irsquom in the process of cataloguing my le in video for the kids.My son has got his drone licence, Irsquove got a drone, my video cameras, my GoPros and Irsquom going to go out and visit all the places I grew up in.If I wait about trying to get the media to do it, theyrsquore not interested in me at all, then there will be no record of what Irsquove done, my le, unless I do it myself.I enjoy it, itrsquos for my grandkids, not really for anything .Buttherersquos any other value, then therersquos a big old internet out there, so people will be able to see it for themselves.DOUGIE MACLEAN TURNS  YEARS OLD ON HIS BIRTHDAY IN SEPTEMBERIrsquom busier this year than Irsquove ever been. Irsquove just come back from Europe. But people say to me ndash when are you going to retire But I remember a famous American actor said, lsquoIf yoursquove got a job, you retire,itrsquos your workndash you just keep doing itrsquo and I thought that was a quite good way of describing what I do.As long as Irsquove got a voice and I can drive and travel, Irsquoll keep on doing it.I love the people, Irsquove got a fantastic group of fans who appreciate what I do, who will come to my shows, and are great fun to be with for an evening.There are two paths you can take as a musicianyou want your face on the front of Q magazine, you sign a deal with a big, major record company, then you might have a bit of fame for two or three years, then you go back to being a taxi driver.Oryou just enjoy playing music, you set up your own independent publishing label, and you go out and do gigs, all kinds of gigs, and thatrsquos whatrsquos been lucky with me.Irsquove managed to have this longevity ndash Irsquom turning  as you say ndash and I think Irsquom getting better as I get older.Even my own songs I sang  years ago Irsquom doing better now for some reason, with that older gravitas that you get.Therersquos something about not being stressed out about it all.Irsquom not at that place in my le where Irsquom worried about reviews, every year I have now is a bonus for me. Irsquove got my family and the kids, Irsquove paid off my house, Irsquom in a good place.Itrsquos an amazing place to be as a musician.

title: 1m-whisky-sauce-e-made-country-fair
story: Foodies and whisky aficionados can delight their taste buds when the one-of-a-kind whisky sauce is served at Galloway Country Fair this weekend.The sauce, made from cask number one of Annandale Distilleryrsquos first unpeated single malt Man orsquo Word, will be used for a recipe in the Fairrsquos Galloway Demo Kitchen.This will be the first and only use of the whisky, named after Robert Burns, before it is out away to mature for a decade. The cask, which is almost five years old, is currently on sale for poundmillion.:Glasgow scientists develop articial tongue to detect fake whiskiesThe unique sauce will be prepared by Bronze Young Chef of the Year, Fraser Cameron, to accompany a Galloway Beef fillet stuffed with St James whisky smoked salmon, meaux mustard mayonnaise and glazed hickory smoked silver skin onions.The sauce will accompany a fillet of beefThe Galloway Country Fair takes place in the grounds of Drumlanrig Castle, whose Manager Anna Fergusson said: ldquoWe strive to make every yearrsquos Fair extra special and this one-in-a-million dish is testament to that!:Whisky investor makes huge gain on bottle of malt#ldquoWersquore honoured to have the whisky making its debut in a recipe at our event alongside an array of fantastic local suppliers.Dorothy Goldie, Secretary of the Galloway Cattle Society, said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be partnering with Galloway Country Fair and with Annandale Distillery to showcase some of Dumfries  Gallowayrsquos most iconic quality food and drink.ldquoLocally reared Galloway Beef combined with local whisky, Fraserrsquos chef skills and the stunning venue of Drumlanrig Castle is an unbeatable combination.Housed in the Food  Drink marquee, The Galloway Demo Kitchen will welcome demonstrations from Fraser Cameron as well as Auldgirth Inn, forager Amy Rankine, Crafty Gin Distillery and Ninefold Rum across the weekend.:Aberdeen claims lsquofirstrsquo still in new chapter for whisky story#Visitors will be able to sample a wide arrayof food and drink suppliers across the grounds of the Fair sponsored by Duncan Plant.The spotlight is on Galloway producers at this yearrsquos Fair after organisers secured support from the Connect Local Regional Food Fun, meaning visitors can sample and buy from a wider range of Galloway suppliers.

title: crufts success for arnage pupil
story: An Arnage School pupil is celebrating after taking part in the world#s biggest dog show for the first time.Nine-year-old Skye Smith qualied for Crufts in June  at Dundee Canine Club with her pet whippet, Marvin.Skye’s mum, Kelly, said everyone in the family was “over the moon” to have qualied.The family took Marvin down to the NEC in Birmingham to compete at this year’s Crufts competition, held from Thursday  to Sunday  March.Kelly said: “The place was so much bigger than we expected.”Once at Birmingham Skye and Marvin went on to compete in the YKC --year-old junior handling class against all other juniors that had qualied though out the year.Skye was delighted to come in second place.Kelly added: “At Crufts she had to handle Marvin in a big ring.“She has to keep Marvin between her and the judge at all times, has to know parts of the dog, what his job is as a dog and also has to do a show.“It was a massive achievement and amazing experience.“Skye said that coming second was the best feeling in the world and she hopes she can qualy again for next year.”Skye has been handling dogs since she was just six-years-old and she has been working towards handling at Crufts since then.She also took part in Scottish Junior Handler of the Year in February at Glasgow and came fourth.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: new homes planned for kemnay
story: Plans have been tabled for  new houses # including five affordable homes # on the outskirts of Kemnay.Malcolm Allan Housebuilders Ltd wants to build the properties on land at Milton Farm opposite the village’s golf course.The site is currently designated for development in the Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan .In a supporting statement, agents Suller and Clark say the layout has been carefully considered to provide a mix of house types, sizes and tenures, with a loop road through the site linking to an existing residential development to its north, which will provide for both road and pedestrian traffic.They says the house designs are “broadly traditional” in terms of design, proportions and materials and will be set within a generously landscaped site.“The site is in a sustainable location, with good links to the village core, to community facilities such as schools, the academy, recreation facilities and retail outlets,” states their report.“The layout and designs have been carefully considered to ensure the highest quality design and materials, that the buildings sit within the containment offered by the site, whilst adding to the strategic landscape and recognising that this is an important and distinctive approach to Kemnay.”Although the applicants say issues pertaining to potential flooding at the site are now resolved, SEPA has meantime lodged an objection to the plans in the absence of a full risk assessment.It says that parts of the application site could be at risk of medium to high risk of flooding.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
